stem: A 62-year-old male is admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to sepsis. Analyze the following information and select the TWO most likely causes of the patient's condition, the MOST likely condition the patient is experiencing, and the TWO most appropriate interventions.

rationale.correct: Sepsis is a major cause of ARDS due to the systemic inflammatory response. Increased alveolar-capillary permeability results in pulmonary edema. Prone positioning helps improve oxygenation by redistributing lung perfusion and ventilation. Low tidal volume ventilation prevents ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) by minimizing alveolar overdistension.
rationale.incorrect: Aspiration pneumonia can cause ARDS, but sepsis is the primary diagnosis here. Hypovolemia is unlikely in ARDS; fluid overload is more typical. High tidal volume ventilation can worsen lung injury. Supplemental oxygen alone will not address the underlying pathology. Nebulized bronchodilators are more appropriate for asthma or COPD exacerbations.
clinicalPearls: Prone positioning can significantly improve oxygenation in ARDS patients.
Low tidal volume ventilation is crucial to prevent VILI.
Sepsis-induced ARDS requires both respiratory support and treatment of the underlying infection.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus on oxygenation without considering the underlying cause or the importance of lung-protective ventilation.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize identifying the root cause of ARDS and select interventions that address both oxygenation and lung protection.

mnemonic.title: ARDS
mnemonic.expansion: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome: Alveolar damage, Reduced compliance, Dyspnea, Severe hypoxemia

reviewUnits.title: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
reviewUnits.content: ARDS is a severe inflammatory lung condition characterized by increased permeability of the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to pulmonary edema and hypoxemia.

itemContext.sbar: 0700: Patient John Doe, 62yo male, admitted to ICU at 0600 with ARDS secondary to sepsis. O2 saturation is 88% on FiO2 60%. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Initial ABG: pH 7.30, PaCO2 55 mmHg, PaO2 58 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L. Pt has a hx of HTN and DM. Blood cultures pending. Currently on norepinephrine for BP support. 0715: Increased FiO2 to 70% per protocol. Assess breath sounds q2h. Continue monitoring vital signs and ABGs. Dr. Smith aware of status.

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content: 0600: Patient admitted to ICU with respiratory distress. SpO2 85% on room air. Patient appears anxious and is using accessory muscles. 0615: Placed on 100% FiO2 via non-rebreather mask. SpO2 improved to 90%. 0630: Patient intubated due to worsening respiratory status. Placed on mechanical ventilation with tidal volume 400 mL, rate 16, FiO2 60%, PEEP 5 cm H2O. 0700: ABG drawn. Norepinephrine infusion started at 5 mcg/min. 0730: Initiated sepsis protocol per physician order.
